comments.body: Wouldn't `isPauseEvent` always be true for `view.uiIsolate.pauseEvent`?  Should we use an assert here instead of a condition on the `if`?

Yuck....

Can you add a DartDoc comment to `vmservice.dart` so that gets capture on the flutter tools side as well?
Sure, added some docs on the `pauseEvent` definition.
Thanks for cleaning up all the other places!
Here too: why not use uri.path?

Why did we remove support for `dillOutputPath` here?  This likely breaks dart-2 inside Google.

/cc @keertip
Can you revert this? The other changes can work w/o this change. Also, we need `dillOutputPath` for internal testing.

See https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/15655#discussion_r176301237.

I believe I tested this to make sure latest version of Flutter works inside Google. Can you share logs that shed some more light why this is breaking?

The latest version would work inside Google regardless because Google hasn't enabled Dart 2 yet (that's what @keertip has a pending CL to enable).  That said, you sound confident this was the right change.  You two should sync up tomorrow to make sure you're both on the same page ðŸ˜„
I tested it by having cl with @keertip's pending cl patched on top of flutter roll I did myself.
Sorry for the spam then - nothing to see here...
Why did we remove support for `dillOutputPath` here?  /cc @keertip
The reason was that in this particular case absolute file path [dillOutputPath] is wrong, because it has to be relative to the device's devfs. That is what [mainPath + '.dill'] is.
Under what circumstances do we end up with a null compilerOutput?
That could happen if compiler was not started or if compiler process crashed unexpectedly.
Do we want to run pub if dirty on reload, or just on restart? Only on restart feels slightly more natural to me, as its handling a bigger change.

The issue I was trying to fix specifically requests hot reload, and I think I agree with that: hot reload should incorporate any changes that it can. In my mind, the main conceptual difference between the two should simply be if you want to preserve state or not (in practice, of course, you are required to restart for other reasons too).

Gotcha. We could also message on reload (`You pubspec is out of date, perform a hot restart to get new dependencies`), but users would then just need to perform the restart. So, this change looks good for both reload and restart.
Can you confirm that this does print some appropriate message (so the user knows that a pub get is running)?

Well.. it wasn't.  This turned out to be because hot reload calls `startProgress` on the logger, and then `pubGet` does the same, and the daemon code uses a custom logger that completely ignores nested progress messages.

I've changed it to print nested progress messages again.  You appear to have disabled them (https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/6677) to make the messages for hot reload and hot restart the same, however, so that might not be the right answer.  Other alternatives would be to add an argument to tell startProgress to not ignore specific messages, or to change pubGet to not start its own progress (but that's nice to have on the command line).

Ah, `Nov 3, 2016`. I think I was trying to address having many small progress items flash by, instead of having a single, unified progress.

IDEs would likely need to upgraded to handle nested progresses, but let me take a look through the PR.

The progress bar is an indeterminate bar on IntelliJ, and it does actually seem to work (it turns on the indeterminate progress bar in the status area when the reload starts, and turns it off when it's done). For this case, there are only a couple of steps (running pub get, and syncing to the device), but I imagine there could be some where it was a lot of steps flying by.

Of course, it looks fine in the IntelliJ "Run" console output, and on the regular command line.

Sounds good! Two steps, where they both don't just flash by, isn't a concern for me. I would just get concerned if we had many very short steps - the text would flash by too quickly for users to read.

> should this also add a new PubContext value that describes how the pub get is being called?

Ah, possibly, based on what the current message says? We may want it tweaked so it says slightly different things based on an initial flutter run vs. a restart.
Does this method need to be awaited?
It doesn't - it's void-returning only resets the terminal and prints `Application finished`.
Might want a comment on this conditional: I had to read it several times to realize what it's doing.

What's the reason for changing from `printError` to `printTrace`? Could this stop the user from getting feedback that it failed? (Seems like in the Daemon's logger we just drop `printTrace` events and only send `printErrors`-  "This is a lot of traffic to send over the wire").

This whole function is run in the context of a Status progress indicator, so we can't print anything to the console until it's stopped. Also, we should never show a stack trace to the user.

The message is still reported, just after the progress indicator is stopped.

this looks like a ui regression? we used to use getElapsedAsMilliseconds() which gives units and suchlike.

(i'll fix it in my timeout patch)
Oh, thanks. I didn't realize `getElapsedAsMilliseconds()` produces formatted string.
Please add a test case to `hot_test.dart` to ensure this gets called.
Added a couple of tests
ditto
Do you to monitor packages file itself and update(rebuild?) ProjectWatcher if it changes?
We have to tear down the runner and restart if packages are updated currently
What are the plans for this in this PR?

Today, we can't update .packages due to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/29186. Essentially we are producing a massive incremental dill (~40MB for the gallery) and that seems to be crashing in part of the shell.

Also related to https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk/issues/36202, where the vmservice does not respond with any caught exceptions.

New implementation is to detect changes to .packages and warn the user that they might have to restart the runner.
Oh, one more question. How is/should this be tested?
Right now it is tested via the `integration/hot_reload_test.dart`, the devicelab, and via some google3 tooling tests. I could make this injectable and add some mock filesystem tests
Actually thanks to the memory filesystem I didn't need to be too fancy here, unit tests added as well.
Offline we discussed seeing if this one alone is sufficient. Also, we should probably include comments at call sites of `asyncGuard`.
Done

comments.body: @zanderso does the async stat call have the same problem with limited file descriptors that reading/writing does?

No, it doesn't have exactly the same problem, however there are two considerations:
1. On Windows, a handle will be briefly opened if the entity is a reparse point. This will only be a problem if this code is going to be encountering a directory containing 10,000+ reparse points.
2. The VM will spawn up to 32 threads per isolate to service async io requests. If this code will be going above that, then it probably makes sense to use a pool (package:pool) even if file descriptor/handle exhaustion is not an issue.
As discussed offline, some comments here about why this is safe, and at the other callsites about why they are still there would be helpful.
Done

comments.body: this method is pretty massive, not a nit, just an observation
Yeah, historically it was really hard to change because we didn't have good test coverage. And the last time I changed it significantly I accidentally broke hot reload for some people :(

This is the fix, it turns out the isolate runnable event was coming from the compute isolate, and removing it caused the test to hang. Instead we can use the point where we start registering package:flutter service extensions as an indication that the hot restart is complete
I think intent of this code was to wait for IsolateRunnable corresponding to the main isolate. Are we not seeing main isolate IsolateRunnable event, only see one for the compute isolate?

Yes, this starts listening too late to pick up the main isolate runnable. I think this is OK to switch to the extension event, because it more accurately measures when we could reasonably perform another hot reload ( though If I see a large change in the benchmarks I can investigate)

This is rather unfortunate. I think we do want to ensure we subscribe to the vm service events before we restart isolate. At a minimum let's add a comment/todo explaining why we are listening for ServiceExtensionAdded instead of IsolateRunnable.
Done
this is for benchmark mode only for, those tests will validate where it stabilizes things
including the additional context in the operation result is required to surface this information in IDEs
Made this error more specific.

This only needs to be performed once at set up - it tells the engine what directory to resolve assets from. Because the engine can load from both the original asset directory and the newly configured directory now, this can be set before any assets are synced
This handler combines the functionality of the removed try/catch below
In the case of a hot reload the views must be the same before and after so caching this is safe for the lifetime of this method (approximately...)
No change here just removed the try catch
It might be a good cleanup to factor out the stuff under this if into a helper function.
Same comment here as in cold_runner.dart
It would be good to have a comment saying why it's ok to ignore errors from this future.
same question here.
I would think these would be the same ðŸ˜•

My guess is because fs.file().stat() generated an additional object in each loop. Although, IIUC, Dart is using generational GC and this kind of short lived objects shouldn't affect the performance so much.
this shouldn't ever be null right?

I added new fields when it succeed. In here, if hot restart succeeded, the event will be sent above, and restartEvent will be null. The code here is to handle failure cases only. Added comment to explain.
Ahh, got it
this is a new event right?
That's right. It's to track the time it spent to launch the app and get hot reload to be ready.
instead of attaching it to this future, why not send it in where appStartedCompleter.complete is called? That would be at right about the same time

The only reason I do it here is because all the `Stopwatch`es  that collect the metrics are in this method, and `appStartedCompleter.complete` is called from another method. E.g. the `appStartedTimer`, is started when this method starts, and ended when `appStartedCompleter.complete` is called.

Or do you think it's better if I pass the `Stopwatch`, and two existing `Duration`s into the `attach()` method instead?
no, I think changing the signature of attach is much worse. this does feel awkward though.
